To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a Php 30,000 loan. She will be using the loan to buy additional supplies and merchandise products like shampoo, cologne, deodorant, perfume, soap, fabric softener, undergarments, and other products needed in her business.

Sally hopes to expand her business and dreams of having a better living. She meets with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her life and business every week;  she also draws strength and inspiration from the fellowship, and the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To pay for additional supplies and merchandise products like clothing, footwear, undergarments, and cosmetics needed in her business.

loans.name: Samuel

texts.en:
Samuel is 33 years old; he is a father of three children. He would like to use the Kiva loan to buy fertilizer, and to support labor costs during maize production.  He needs to buy fertilizer to increase production. With the profits from his farming, he wishes to invest in his business so that in the future, he can acquire machines and tractors that will enhance his farming capacity.

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: To buy more fertilizer and support labor costs during maize production

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To cover the entire tuition fees

loans.name: Gerley

texts.en: Gerley is from San Jose, Aurora. She is 32 years old, married, and has two children. She manages her general store properly, and she was able to repay her previous loan from GDMPC. To add to her working inventory capital, she took out a new loan of 20,000 PHP to buy more grocery items to sell, such as canned goods and dairy products. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her family's general living conditions.

loans.use: to buy more grocery items, such as canned foods and dairy products, to sell in her store.

loans.name: Almira

texts.en: As a married mother of three children, Almira works hard to support her family. She has a business selling electronic loads in the Philippines, and she also earns additional income from food vending and from selling ready-to-wear clothing. Almira is borrowing PHP 13,000 through NWTF in order to buy additional prepaid load to sell to her customers. Almira has been sustaining her business activities with her past four loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream of building and expanding her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to buy additional prepaid electronic load to sell to her customers.

loans.name: Toul's Group

texts.en: Toul lives in the Moung Russey district of Battambang province, Cambodia. She is 41 years old and has four children. Her main source of income to support her family is farming rice on three hectares of her own farmland. She has been in this business for ten years and is able to earn about 36,700 KHR per day. Toul is leading a group of two members to apply for loans of the same amount each, 1,400,000 KHR. This is her fourth loan cycle with VisionFund, Kiva’s partner. The past loan, which she has fully repaid, helped her to improve her household living conditions. As the leader, she is planning to use her portion of the loan to buy fertilizer and insecticide for her farm. She hopes to earn more income so as achieve good living conditions.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer and insecticide for her farm.

loans.name: Marko

texts.en: Marko wants to thank all of the lenders for helping him to pay for spare parts for his tractor. Currently he has another job, in a printing house. Marko is engaged to be married, and he plans to get married soon. He would like to finish the renovations needed at his house. He wants to finish both the inside and outside walls of his house. He is applying for his second loan, to pay for these renovations. The loan will help him to reach his dream of having children and living there with his family in the future. He is very thankful to all of the Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to renovate his house so he will be ready to marry his fiancée and live there with his family.

loans.name: Nimfa

texts.en:
This is Nimfa. She previously took out a 10,000 PHP loan, which she used for the maintenance of her apartment and to buy a variety of ready-to-wear products. Her earnings were a big help with  the education of her children and with their personal, household and business expenditures. She would like to apply for another loan, of 50,000 PHP, to have her apartment repaired and also to buy ready-to-wear products. Her profits from the business will definitely help her to sustain her daily needs and to pay the educational expenses of her children. She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart. Nimfa hopes that her business will continue to flourish. She meets every week with her co-fellowship* group members to share stories of her work and to draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies. 

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay micrfinance loans.

loans.use: to pay for the maintenance of her apartment and to buy a variety of ready-to-wear products to sell.

loans.name: Hoeun

texts.en:
Generally most Cambodian people living in the countryside prefer the farming business to other business activities. They think that it is a kind of traditional occupation, which is passed down from their ancestors and parents. Among them, Hoeun, a 33-year-old married woman, also has been managing her farm for more than 10 years, primarily growing rice and cassava. and earning a net income approximately of KHR 42,000 per day. With the current income, Hoeun is able to cover her family’s living expenses such as food and allowances for her two school-aged children.

During this period, their rice crop is growing rapidly and needs more fertilizers to accelerate it. That’s why she has applied for a loan in the amount of KHR 2,000,000 to buy a few sacks of fertilizer for her rice crop and also hire people to remove unwanted plants from her cassava plantation. She awaits your kindness and relies on your generosity.

loans.use: to buy a few sacks of fertilizer for her rice crop and also hire people to remove unwanted plants from her cassava plantation.

loans.name: Makumbusho Group

texts.en:
Victoria, who is in her late 20s, is single and has one daughter who goes to school.  

She has been running a business of selling second-hand clothes since 2011.  She works from 9:00 a.m. to 7:00 p.m. daily and is able to make a good monthly profit. 

This will be Victoria's second loan from Tujijenge Tanzania. She used the previous loan to increase the second-hand clothes stock and has paid back the loan successfully. She used the profit for household expenses. 

She will use this loan to buy more stock of second-hand clothes to resell. She dreams of owing another second-hand clothes shop and a beauty salon.  

Victoria will share this loan with her loan group "Makumbusho" with five members who will hold each other accountable for paying back the loan.

loans.use: to buy more stock of second-hand clothes to resell.

loans.name: Catalina

texts.en:
Catalina is a hardworking entrepreneur who has a general store business in the Philippines. 

She is borrowing PHP 16,000 through NWTF in order to purchase additional groceries to sell to customers.

Catalina successfully paid back her previous loan and is now requesting a new loan to further build her business.

NWTF is presenting Catalina's business profile again in support of her efforts to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to purchase additional groceries to sell.

loans.name: Edouard

texts.en: Edouard is 50 years old. He is a father of nine children. He has sold different drinks such as sodas and beers for the past eighteen years. With the loan, he would like to buy more  sodas for sale. The profits from the business will be used to pay school fees for the children.

loans.use: To buy more sodas to sell.

loans.name: Noel

texts.en:
Noel, aged 36, is a father of four and married to a farmer. He would like to use his Kiva loan to support labor costs and buy fertilizers during maize production. He needs to buy fertilizer in order to increase production. With profits from his farming he wishes to invest in his business so that in the future he can acquire machines and tractors that will enhance his farming capacity.

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: To buy more fertilizers and support labor costs during maize production

loans.name: Alejandro

texts.en:
Alejandro is a 42-year-old man from the town of Panglao, Bohol. He is married with thtree children ages 19,17 and 3.  He  is engaged  in making handicrafts to help augment the income of their household. His business  started less than a year ago. He is asking for a loan to buy lumber and paint, to produce more and increase sales.

In the future, he  hopes to expand his handicrafts business and increase business profitability for the sake of his children’s education.

loans.use: to buy lumber and paint

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy work tools.

loans.name: Genalyn

texts.en:
This is Genalyn. She previously accessed a 50,000 Philippine peso (PHP) loan that she used to purchase more quantities and varieties of grocery items, toiletries and beverages needed in her business. Her earnings were a big help in her personal, household and business expenditures. She would like to apply for another 50,000 PHP loan to buy groceries, toiletries, beverages and other products to add to her current inventory. The more items displayed at her store the better! More items to sell will result in better profit. Her profits from the business will definitely help her to meet her daily needs. She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart.

Genalyn dreams that her business will continue and won't close. She hopes that her whole family will be in good health always. She meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her life and business every week and also to draw strength and inspiration from the fellowship and the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to pay for grocery items, toiletries and beverages needed in her business.

loans.name: Analiza

texts.en:
This time, Analiza is requesting a new loan of PHP 25,000 to buy fishing net, bamboo and other fishing equipment. 

Her general store business was previously funded through NWTF and Kiva, and it continues to provide her and her family with income that is improving their quality of life.

loans.use: to buy fishing net, bamboo and other fishing equipment.

loans.name: Mondaynah

texts.en: Mondaynah is 47 years old and lives in Sinkor in Montserrado County. She is  married  and is a local businessman. They have five children between 9 and 18 years old, who are in school and live at home. For the past ten years she has been selling charcoal in her community. She has lots of customers and she makes a lot of profit. She spends 8 hours on her business each day from Monday to Saturday. She is requesting a loan to purchase more charcoal by the bag for her business. She plans to build a house for her children.

loans.use: to purchase more charcoal by the bag for her business.

loans.name: Asha

texts.en:
Asha is a married mother with two children, both of whom attend school. They live at their own house that has electricity but not piped water. 

She operate a food stall business, selling at the market to her neighbors and passersby, and  in addition she sells charcoal. She faces a major challenge of competition from other food stall operators in her business. 

With Kshs 50,000 she wants to purchase cooking oil, maize flour, wheat flour and rice for resale. She dreams of expanding to her business to earn more income in the future.

loans.use: to purchase cooking oil, maize flour, wheat flour and rice for resale

loans.name: Julius

texts.en:
Julius is a 32-year-old married man with two children. 

He is a trained clinical officer and works at the community health center. He is the third born in a family of five and takes care of his parents and two siblings. 

Julius ventured into the retail trade in 2011 to trade in mobile phone accessories and general merchandise, since his employment income was not sufficient to take care of his extended family. He later partnered with a local telecommunications company to offer mobile money transfer services to the community from his shop. He has employed one shop attendant to coordinate the money transfer services and attend to customers in need of other products from the shop. The business has been doing well so far. 

In response to the recurring costs and health effects associated with candles and paraffin lamps that are commonly used in the area, Julius introduced the solar lanterns from BrazAfric in the year 2012. Electricity is only available at shopping centers and therefore the products got a very good reception because of their economic and social benefits. They provide safe and bright lighting and come with a mobile phone charging function. Their demand has since gone up and now he cannot buy adequate stocks to meet the demand. 

Julius has been buying the lanterns for cash. From the Kiva financing option at BrazAfric, he is now seeking financing to purchase the solar lanterns for stocking and selling to the community. He has a good rapport with the area residents and predicts that, based on the economic and social benefits and previous performance, the solar lanterns will sell fast and boost his income.

loans.use: To buy solar lanterns.

loans.name: Julijana

texts.en:
Julijana lives in a minority community of Kosovo. She is 23 and single, living with her parents who receive a pension. 

Julijana is a student of the economic faculty and also works doing accounting for a private company to support her family. Her parents' social pension and her salary is still not enough money to be able to repair the roof of her house, which is in immediate need because it leaks during the rain. 

Julijana is requesting a loan for the first time so that she can renovate the roof and is hoping that the loan will solve their problem and keep them healthy, warm and comfortable in the upcoming winter and rainy season. Her future goal is to complete her studies and to have her own business. She wants to thank all of the lenders for the support!

loans.use: To renovate the roof of her house.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to pay for her education fee and buy studying equipment to support her studying.

loans.name: Aravela

texts.en:
Aravela is 58 years old, married and has three children. She is a very hardworking entrepreneur.

Aravela has a beauty parlor business in the Philippines. She has been in this business for 24 years.

Aravela requested a PHP 15,000 loan through NWTF to buy cosmetics supplies for her beauty parlor.

In the future, Aravela would like to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy cosmetics supplies for her beauty parlor.

loans.name: Kashif

texts.en:
Kashif is the age of 27, a young and energetic man living with his three children in the area of Lahore, Pakistan. He has been doing this business for many years and getting reasonable income for his family. His sibling is too young, and his grandfather had been doing the same business for many years so Kashif got all the buffaloes in inheritance.

He is a milkman by trade and he sells milk and produces yogurt and butter. He has six buffaloes; he gets milk two times in a day from all of them. He sells milk at the front of his house and provides door to door milk to his customers also.

He is the only earning person at home; he is responsible for all household expenses. He is facing problems coping with the expenses due to rapid increase in inflation.

Kashif requested a loan from Kiva’s field partner BRAC Pakistan, so that he would be able to buy one buffalo for more milk. He will use a portion of this loan for the maintenance of his cowshed as well. He hopes that his production will increase and he could easily cope with inflation.

Kashif says thank to Kiva and to its field partner BRAC Pakistan.

loans.use: To buy another buffalo for  more milk to sell.

loans.name: Gjemile

texts.en:
Gjemile is a 24-year-old Roma woman living in a Roma community in Kosovo. She is a married, raising two children ages 4 and 5 years old. Her husband cuts wood for a living and she stays at home taking care of the children and the house. The income that her husband brings in is only enough to support the family on a daily basis, however their home is in urgent need of a roof and they have not been able to address the problem. 

Gjemile is requesting a loan from KosInvest to purchase building materials to renovate the roof and the outside of the house before the rain, snow and cold weather begin to affect the family, their health and their living conditions. Gjemile is grateful to KosInvest lenders for improving the family's living conditions and standard of living.

loans.use: To purchase building materials for renovating the roof and the outside of their house

loans.name: Savat's Group

texts.en:
Originally from a rural area located in Sangke district of Battambang province, Savat is married and a 26-year-old mother of four dependent children. Three of them are in school while another one is too young for school. 

Her major source of income is rice farming. She has been earning money through this business for several years and earns about 40,600 KHR per day. Savat has been with VisionFund six times and completely repaid all her past loans with success. The positive result from her past loans has enabled her to improve her living conditions and keep her children in school. 

Now she has formed a group of five borrowers to get a new loan. The total amount of the entire group loan is 4,500,000 KHR. As the leader, Savat will use her loan portion to buy rice seeds and fertilizer for her crops, and she will spend some portion of her loan to pay for transplanting fees. She hopes to increase her income to expand her business so she can improve her family's lifestyle.

loans.use: To buy rice seeds and fertilizer for her crops.

loans.name: Charlotte

texts.en:
Charlotte is 32 years old. She is married and has two children, age 4 and 7. 

With a Kiva loan, she would like to support labor costs and buy fertilizers during maize production. She needs to buy fertilizer in order to increase their production. With profits from her farming, she wishes to invest in her business so that in the future she can acquire machines and tractors that will enhance her farming capacity.

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: To buy more fertilizers and support labor costs during maize production.

loans.name: Catalina

texts.en: Catalina is a 71-year-old woman from the town of Baclayon, Bohol. She is married with eight grown children. Her husband worked as a barber to support their family. She runs a sari-sari (variety store). She sells various items like canned goods, noodles, coffee, biscuits, cooking oil, eggs, shampoo and soap. Her business started more than 10 years ago. She is asking for a loan to buy soft drinks, beverages, condiments, toiletries, other dry goods, and firewood to maintain the inventory of her store. In the future, she hopes to expand her sari-sari store business to have a sustainable source of income.

loans.use: to buy soft drinks, beverages, condiments, toiletries, other dry goods, and firewood

loans.name: Rosa Maria

texts.es: Rosa es una mujer de 50 años de edad, acompañada, con un hijo bajo su cargo, su negocio es la venta de comida, gaseosas, golosinas en su comunidad desde  hace 11 años. Tiene de ser cliente de la institución 1 año, el crédito lo está solicitando para la compra de gaseosas de medio litro de diferentes sabores, gatorade, jugos, agua purificada, golosinas, frutas para la elaboración de frescos como cebada, cálala, azúcar, melón, para la elaboración de comida  carne de res, carne de cerdo, arroz, aceite, carne de pollo, repollo, carbon,leña,etc.
texts.en: Rosa is a 50 year old woman. She is in a common law marriage and is raising a son. Her business has been selling food, sodas, and snacks in her community for 11 years. She has been a client of the institution for 1 year. The loan she is asking for is to buy half liters of soda in different flavors, Gatorade, juice, snacks, and ingredients to make fresh juices such as barley, cálala, sugar, and melon, as well as to prepare food, such as beef, pork, rice, oil, chicken, cabbage, coal, firewood, etc.

loans.use: to buy half liter sodas in different flavors, Gatorade, juices, distilled water, snacks, and ingredients to make fresh juice, such as barley, cálala, sugar, and melon, as well as to prepare food, such as beef, pork, rice, oil, chicken, cabbage, coal, firewood, etc.

loans.name: Banakane 7 Group

texts.fr:
Les membres du groupe BANAKANE 7 sont toutes  des femmes mariées  ayant une moyenne d’âge de  38 ans, 4 enfants et vivant toutes dans des  familles polygames à  Bandiagara, 5ème région administrative du Mali. 
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de mener à bien leurs activités maraîchères en cette fin d’hivernage. 
Elles sont à leur premier prêt avec l’institution.
La spéculation cultivée est essentiellement l’oignon avec Mme Hawa Piré
debout en première  position de la droite  vers la gauche  sur la photo. 
Avec son prêt, elle compte acheter  de la semence et des engrais. La production est vendue au niveau du village, de Bandiagara et Mopti, après la récolte à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes. 
Elle compte réaliser un bénéfice de 22.000  Francs CFA en fin de campagne Ce bénéfice lui permettra d’aider son mari dans les dépenses familiales et réinvestir le reste dans les activités.
texts.en: The members of Banakane 7 Group are all married women with an average age of 38 and 4 children.  They all live in polygamous families in Bandiagara, the 5th largest administrative region in Mali.  They work with Soro Yiriwaso, a micro-finance organization, in order to conduct their gardening business at the end of winter.  They are on their first loan with the organization.  The main crop is essentially onions, grown by Ms. Hawa Pire, standing at the far right in the photo.  With her loan, she plans to buy seeds and fertilizers. After the harvest, the crops are sold at the village level, in Bandiagara and Mopti, to male and female customers.  She plans to earn a profit of 22,000 CFA at the end of the season. This profit will allow her to help her husband pay for family expenses and to reinvest in her business.

loans.use: to buy seeds and fertilizers.

loans.name: Irma

texts.es: Irma de 54 años de edad vive en casa propia con su esposo y sus dos hijos, ella se dedica a trabajar en su molino, procesando todo tipo de alimentos, como maíz, frijoles, harinas, salsas, entre otros.tambien posee una pequeña tienda en su lugar de residencia Tiene ya algún tiempo con el negocio y posee amplia experiencia que le ayuda a generar muy buenas ganancias, es muy conocida por las personas de la localidad y se ha hecho de mucha clientela que la prefiere por la calidad, por los precios accesibles y por el servicio inigualable siempre a la orden de los clientes, es una mujer  emprendedor, dedicada a su labor, Irma solicita a INTEGRAL un crédito que le permita comprar granos basicos, aceite, golosinas, huevos, refrescos, etc. para surtir mas su tienda. Tiene buenas referencias de pago y es responsable, se compromete a cancelar la deuda y a la vez tiene fe que llevará seguridad económica a su familia.
texts.en: Irma is 54 years old and lives in her own house with her husband and two children.  Irma makes a living in her mill, processing all types of foods, such as corn, beans, flours, sauces, and more.  Irma also has a small shop in her home.  She has had the business for some time and has experience, which helps her to generate very good profits.  Irma is known to people in the area and she has many customers who prefer her for the quality, affordable prices, and for the unbeatable service.  Irma is enterprising, and dedicated to her work.  Irma is applying for a loan from "INTEGRAL" - this will allow her to buy basic grains, oil, sweets, eggs, soft drinks, and more to stock up her shop.  Irma has a good credit rating and is responsible.  She promises to pay off her loan and she has faith that this loan will bring more financial security to her family.

loans.use: to buy basic grains, oil, sweets, eggs, soft drinks, and more.

loans.name: Titintaya De Huatajata Group

texts.es:
La A.C. “TITINTAYA DE HUATAJATA”  Iniciarán el cuarto ciclo en Pro Mujer, como parte del Centro Focal de Copacabana, está compuesta por nueve integrantes y está dirigida por una mesa directiva donde la señora Victoria es la Presidenta. Los negocios que las integrantes de la asociación comunal llevan adelante son variados entre ellos existen: venta de pescado, venta y compra de ganado, artesano en tejido, venta de api, venta de comida, construcción.

El crédito que sacaran beneficiara a pequeñas microempresarias donde la señora Victoria es integrante, ella indica que hace tres años que integra Pro Mujer, ingresando por invitación de una amiga que es socia de la institución. En la actualidad ella tiene un negocio de venta de comida; cuenta que este negocio lo emprendió por recomendación de su esposo.
 
El crédito que ahora sacará es para el aumento de capital (compra de pescado fresco) que adquirirá de las ferias de la Ciudad de El Alto y posteriormente a la elaboración lo comercializará en su espacio de venta. Esta forma de trabajo le permite generar recursos para mantener en lo posible a su hogar pues ella vive en unión libre y tiene cinco hijos.  

Cuando se le consulta qué le gusta de Pro Mujer, ella responde que le gusta que el préstamo favorezca a las mujeres.
texts.en:
The communal bank Titintaya of Huatajata is beginning their fourth cycle with Pro Mujer as part of the Centro Focal de Copacabana. It is made up of nine members and is directed by a board where Victoria is the President. The business that the members of the communal bank are in are varied and among them are: sale of fish, buying and selling of livestock, art of weaving, sale of api [popular drink made from purple corn, cinnamon, water, and sugar], food sales, and construction.

The loan they are requesting will benefit small micro-enterprises where Victoria is a member. She says that she joined Pro Mujer about three years ago, joining at the invitation of a friend who was a member of the institution. Currently she has a business selling food. She started this business at the recommendation of her husband.

The loan that she is now taking is to increase her capital(to buy fresh fish) that she will buy from the markets in the city of El Alto and later she will sell them in her retail space. This form of work permits her to generate income more easily in order to maintain the household as she lives in a life-partnership and has five children. 

When asked what she likes about Pro Mujer she said she likes that the loans favor women.

loans.use: to buy fish to sell

loans.name: Las Estrellitas Group

texts.es: Los socios del grupo “LAS ESTRELLITAS” se encuentran muy contentos por estar pasando el 02 ciclo. Raquel tiene 30 años es casada con tres hijos educando. Hace 3 años se dedica a la venta de productos de belleza actividad que le ha permitido mejorar la calidad de vida de su familia y a la vez le sirve como distracción. Los fines de semana brinda servicios de mantenimiento. El préstamo lo invertirá en la compra de productos de belleza que están en oferta así poderlas vender a otro precio y obtener mejores ganancias. Su mayor deseo es tener una casa propia. El grupo agradece a los inversionistas KIVA por el préstamo brindado. Raquel es la tercera persona del lado izquierdo viste chompa negra.
texts.en: The members of the "Las Estrellitas" group are very happy to be going through their second loan cycle.  Raquel is 30 years old, married and is bringing up three children.  She has been making a living selling beauty products for three years.  This has allowed her to improve her family's quality of life, and the work also keeps her busy.  At the weekend Raquel does maintenance work.  Raquel will invest this loan in beauty products which are on offer.  She can then sell them at a higher price and earn higher profits.  Raquel's biggest wish is to have her own house.  The group is grateful to Kiva lenders for this loan.  In the photo, Raquel is the third person on the left, wearing a black jumper.

loans.use: to buy beauty products.

loans.name: Denis De Jesus

texts.es: Denis es un hombre de 60 años de edad, casado, su negocio es comerciante de frutas, verduras en el mercado de Masaya y agricultor  desde hace 20 años. Tiene  de ser cliente de la institución 1 año, lo cual ha demostrado ser una persona muy responsable. El crédito lo está requiriendo para la compra de cosecha de tamarindo y corte de ayote.
texts.en: Denis is a 60 year old man. He is married and his business is selling fruit and vegetables in the Masaya market, as well as being a farmer for 20 years.He has been a client of the institution for 1 year, and has shown himself to be a very responsible person. He needs the loan to buy harvested tamarind as well as to harvest ayote.

loans.use: to buy  harvested tamarind and to harvest ayote.

loans.name: Emma

texts.en: Emma is a 62-year-old married woman with eight children. She is a very hard working entrepreneur. Emma has a fishing business in the Philippines. Emma requested a 25,000 PHP loan amount through NWTF in order to buy fishing gear and other equipment. Emma has been in this business for twelve years. In the future, Emma would like to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy fishing gear and other equipment.

loans.name: Lucila

texts.es: Lucila, a sus 64 años de edad, es casada y madre de dos hijas. Desde muy joven inició su propio negocio en la ciudad de Bogotá, una tienda de abarrotes con la que pudo aportar a la economía de su hogar y brindarles educación a sus hijas, pero luego, se trasladó de ciudad en compañía de su familia, buscando mejores oportunidades, inició nuevamente su tienda y, con esfuerzo, empeño y dedicación ha logrado cumplir con los objetivos propuestos y mejorando poco a poco la calidad de vida de toda la unidad familiar. Actualmente solicita el apoyo del crédito para comprar un enfriador, una pesa electrónica y surtido al por mayor (mecato, galletería, gaseosas, granos, pastas, dulces), de esta forma fortalecerá su negocio y podrá ofrecer un servicio de muy buena calidad, además de ofrecer más variedad de productos para satisfacer los gustos y necesidades de los clientes. Esto ayudará a incrementar las ventas y los ingresos familiares, además tendrá la oportunidad de avanzar hacia el cumplimiento de su sueño, que es montar una distribuidora de alimentos grande, rentable y sostenible en el tiempo, que le permita disfrutar de un mejor bienestar al lado de los que ama.
texts.en: Sixty-four-year-old Lucila is married and a mother to two daughters.  At a very young age she started a business in Bogotá - a grocery store, with which she could bring home an income and give her children an education.  However, later in life, Lucila and her family moved city in the search of new opportunities.  There Lucila opened a new shop and, with effort, determination and dedication, she has managed to achieve her objectives and improve all the family's quality of life.  Lucila is currently applying for a loan to buy a fridge, electronic scales, and to buy stock in bulk (pastries, biscuits, fizzy drinks, grains, pastas, and sweets).  With this she can strengthen her business and offer very good service to her customers, as well as ofering them a greater variety of products to satisfy all their tastes and needs.  This will help to increase sales and income for the family.  In addition Lucila will be able to progress as she works towards her dream of having a big, profitable, and sustainable fodd distribution centre.  This will allow Lucila to enjoy better well-being alongside her family.

loans.use: to buy a fridge, electronic scales, and to buy stock in bulk (pastries, biscuits, fizzy drinks, grains, pastas, and sweets).

loans.name: Chari

texts.en:
Chari is a single married mother of two school-going children. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees. She has operated a retail shop business for the past five years, selling household consumables like wheat flour and maize flour from home to her neighbours. She faces the challenge of competition in her business, and she dreams of expanding to a wholesale shop in the future.

With this 50,000 Kenyan shilling loan, she wants to purchase bundles of wheat flour, maize flour and cooking oil to sell.

loans.use: to purchase bundles of wheat flour, maize flour and cooking oil to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To build walls for his car wash

loans.name: Maria Mabel

texts.en: Maria Mabel is a 42-year-old woman from the town of Baclayon, Bohol. She is married with 4 children ages 23, 21, 18, and 16 year old. She provides tailoring services. She makes dresses, all kinds of dress adjustments, and provides other related services. Aside from tailoring, she raises and sells hogs to help augment the income of their household. She started both of her businesses 5 years ago. She is asking for a loan to buy additional piglets so that she can sell more of them in a certain period of time. In the future, she hopes to expand both of her businesses and increase business profitability for her children’s education.

loans.use: to buy additional piglets

loans.name: La

texts.en: La is 51 years old. He is married and resides with five children in Kampong Speu Province, Cambodia. He is a construction worker who makes an income of $4 per day. Three of his children are employed. They earn about $14 daily. In order to improve his family’s transportation, La is requesting a loan of $1200 to purchase a motorbike for commuting. This purchase will help his children go to work on time and save money on transportation expenses. In the future, he would like to fix his house and help his children earn a higher education.

loans.use: to purchase a motorbike for commuting

loans.name: Marilyn

texts.en:
Marilyn is very thankful for the financial assistance extended to her. She was able to buy the grocery items needed in her variety store. She has had his business for more than twenty years now. Her loan is also helpful in the education of her children. Her income from the loan assisted in their everyday expenses at home.

She would like to apply for another 50,000 PHP loan for her to buy groceries, toiletries, beverages and other products to add in her inventory. The more items displayed at the store the better. More items to sell will result in better profit. Her profits from the business will definitely help sustain her family’s daily needs and the children’s education expense. She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart.

Marilyn hopes that her business will last and dreams to have a better living.  She meets up with her co-fellowship* members every week to share stories of her work and to draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis.  A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners.  The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To pay for grocery items, toiletries and beverages needed in her business.

loans.name: Mweruphe

texts.en: Mwaruphe is a hardworking woman who has been able to raise her family through loans from Yehu and Kiva. She says thanks to all! The previous loan helped her to buy more animals to sell, and she made good profit. In addition, she also sells consumer goods in a small shop. Here again, she comes to you requesting another loan of 50,000 Kenyan shillings to buy more goats to add to her stock for sale. She appreciates the support.

loans.use: to buy more goats to add to her stock for sale

loans.name: Susan

texts.en: Susan lives in Sinkor.  She is 45 years old, and she is married to an office worker. She is a sixth grade dropout. Over the past 16 years she has been selling fish in the local market in order to help her husband in the home. One challenge she faces is the rainy season. She started this business with a small amount from her husband. She says handling some money to help in her home makes her happy about her business. She is requesting a loan to purchase more fish for her  business.  She wants to expand her business in the near future.

loans.use: to purchase more fish for her  business,

loans.name: Venuste

texts.en:
Venuste is married to a farmer and they both have three children. He has been a maize farmer for the past six years. With the loan, he would like to support labor costs and buy fertilizer during maize production. He needs to buy fertilizer in order to increase production. With profits from farming he wishes to invest in his business so that in the future he can acquire machines and tractors that will enhance his farming capacity.

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain under served by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: To buy more fertilizer and cover labor costs during maize production

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase a greater quantity of maize, thus increasing her current inventory levels

loans.name: Jessenia Maribel

texts.es:
En el sitio la pila del cantón Montecristi se reúne cada quince días el Banco Comunal  Para el Futuro De la Mujer. Este lugar es muy conocido en la provincia y en el país por su rica cultura tradicional, en este lugar se puede encontrar una gran variedad de  artesanía que son elaboradas por sus habitantes siguiendo las costumbres tradicionales.
En este lugar vive la señora Jessenia, tiene 35 años de edad, está casada y de esta relación tienen cuatro hijos de 20, 19, 12 y 10 años de edad, las dos menores estudian en colegio y escuela. Su esposo es empleado privado.
Doña Jessenia para valerse por sí misma y con esto ayudar con  los gastos del hogar se dedica al comercio, ella compra y venta de  artesanía hechos en tagua, solo vende en este material porque su negocio es comprar ya sea en Portoviejo o en Los Bajos estos productos para luego enviarlos a los Estados Unidos lugar donde desde hace muchos años vive su papá que es el encargado de recibir y distribuir estos objetos en dicho lugar. Lleva 4 años que se dedica a esta actividad con la cual se gana algo honradamente por el bienestar de su familia.
Este crédito es para comprar más artesanía de todas las formas y modelos para exportar. Lleva 8 años en el  Banco Comunal  y le gusta porque con uno de los créditos empezó su negocio. 
Su sueño es darles lo mejor a sus hijos
texts.en:
In La Pila in the Montecristi canton, the Para el Futuro De la Mujer communal bank meets every two weeks. This place is very well known in the province and in the country for its rich cultural tradition. Here you can find a wide variety of handmade crafts made by its inhabitants, following traditional customs. 

This is where Jessenia lives. She is 36, married and has four children from her marriage aged  20, 19, 12 and 10. The two youngest are in high school and elementary school. In order to take care of herself and help with the household expenses, Jessenia has a business. She buys and sells hand made tagua items. She only sells things made from that material because her business is buying these products either in Portoviejo or in Los Bajos and sending them to the United States where her father has lived for many years. He is the one who receives them and distributes them there. She has been doing this activity for 4 years. She makes an honest living for her family's well being.

This loan is to buy more handmade crafts of all types and models for export. She has been in the communal bank for 8 years and she likes it because she started her business with one of these loans. Her dream is to give the best to her children.

loans.use: to buy handmade crafts.

loans.name: Virgina

texts.en: Please meet a 5th grade dropout who is now a talented business woman from Liberia.  According to her, she established her business by working for a big businesswoman in her community from whom she got some money to start this business.  She has been selling from Monday to Saturday, spending ten hours each day on her business selling garlic and rice in the local market, for three years now.  She described herself as talented businesswoman.  She enjoys her business because she has a lot of customers. She is requesting a loan to purchase more garlic and rice for her business.  She lives in Sinkor. She is now married, 35 years old, and has four children between 3 and 19 years old.  Her plan is to build her house.

loans.use: to purchase more garlic and rice for her business.

loans.name: Behar

texts.en: Behar is a single, hard working young man who lives with his entire family in the southern part of Kosovo. In order to earn a living, Behar has been working as a stone cutter, creating decorating for buildings, homes and restaurants. He had been working for a private company for a low salary and has now decided to open his own business doing the same work. In order to achieve this he is asking for a loan in order to purchase a machine and other construction materials he will need. The loan will help him to be able to start his business and generate a larger income than when he was working for a company. He is hoping in the future to expand his business and eventually get married. He is very grateful for this support.

loans.use: To purchase a machine and other construction materials for his new business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to increase her current inventory levels, hence, allowing her to sell greater quantities of cooked rice

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy work tools.

loans.name: Letty Verónica

texts.es:
En el sitio la pila del cantón Montecristi se reúne cada quince días el Banco Comunal  Para el Futuro De la Mujer. Este lugar es muy conocido en la provincia y en el país por su rica cultura tradicional, en este lugar se puede encontrar una gran variedad de  artesanía que son elaboradas por sus habitantes siguiendo las costumbres tradicionales.
En este lugar vive la señora Letty tiene 37 años de edad, está casada y de esta relación tienen tres hijos de 20, 12 y 6  años de edad, estudian en Universidad, colegio y escuela. Su esposo trabaja para el Estado.
Doña Letty con la intención de ganar algo por su cuenta y con esto poder ayudar a su esposo con los gastos que genera el hogar se dedica al comercio, ella vende ropa de todo tipo y productos de Avon, Yanbal y Belcorp (productos de belleza, cosméticos, perfumería y accesorios para damas). Su forma de venta es puerta a puerta y también en su casa donde llegan muchos clientes, tres o cuatro  días a la semana sale a recorrer con sus productos los mismos que deja a crédito y que  cobra cada 8 días. Lleva  8 años que se dedica a esta actividad con la cual se gana algo  que emplea en los gastos de estudios para sus hijos.
Este crédito lo va emplear en comprar más mercadería como: ropa,  perfumes, cremas y bisutería.  Lleva 4 años en el Banco Comunal y le gusta porque con los créditos ella financia su negocio el cual le permite salir adelante. 
Su sueño es tener un carro para realizar sus recorridos.
texts.en:
The communal bank Futuro de la Mujer meets every two weeks in La Pila, Montecristi Canton. This place is very well known in the province and the country for its rich traditional culture. Here one can find a great variety of craftsmanship made by the residents in the traditional ways.

Letty lives here. She is 37 years old, married with three children who are 20, 12, and 6 years old. She studied at university, college, and in school. Her husband works for the state.

Letty, with the intention of earning something on her own with which to help her husband with the household expenses, works in commerce. She sells clothing and and all types of Avon products, Yanbal and Belcorp (beauty products, cosmetics, perfume and women’s accessories.) She goes from door to door and also sells from her home where many customers shop. Three or four days a week she travels about with her products, leaving them on credit and collecting every 8 days. She has been in this business for 8 years which has earned her something to put towards school fees for her children.

She is going to use this loan to buy more merchandise such as clothing, perfume, creams, and jewelry. She has been with the communal bank for 4 years and she likes it because the loans finance her business permitting her to get ahead. Her dream is to have a car to make her rounds.

loans.use: bo buy clothing, perfume, creams, and jewelry to sell in her door-to-door and home-based business

loans.name: Alphonse

texts.en:
Alphonse is 52 years old. He is married and has five children. He would like to use a Kiva loan to support labor costs and buy fertilizers during maize production.  He needs to buy fertilizer in order to increase production. With profits from his farming he wishes to invest in his business so that in the future he can acquire machines and tractors that will enhance his farming capacity.

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers and support labor costs during maize production

loans.name: Diana Maricela

texts.es:
En el sitio la pila del cantón Montecristi se reúne cada quince días el Banco Comunal  Para el Futuro De la Mujer. Este lugar es muy conocido en la provincia y en el país por su rica cultura tradicional, en este lugar se puede encontrar una gran variedad de  artesanía que son elaboradas por sus habitantes siguiendo las costumbres tradicionales.
En este lugar  vive la señora Diana, tiene 21 años  de edad, está casada pero aun no tienen hijos.  Ella estudia párvulo  en una  universidad de Manta. Lleva en el Banco Comunal ya 2 años y le gustan los créditos ya que estos le ayudan a financiar su negocio.
Doña Diana parar ayudarse más que todo con los gastos que generan sus estudios ya que a su marido no le alcanza para esto, con la ayuda de los créditos empezó un pequeño negocio en su casa, ella vende sodas, aguas, jugos entre otras cosas. Así ella logra ganarse algo por su cuenta y seguir con sus estudios pensando en el futuro tener un mejor porvenir para ella y los hijos cuando lleguen.
Este crédito es para comprar aguas, jugos y sodas. 
Sus sueños son terminar sus estudios y tener su casa propia pues viven con familiares.
texts.en:
In La Pila in the Montecristi canton, the Para el Futuro De la Mujer meets every two weeks. This place is very well known in the province and in the country for its rich cultural tradition. Here we can find a wide variety of handmade crafts made by its inhabitants following cultural traditions.

Here lives Diana. She is 21 and married, but doesn't have children yet. She is studying early childhood education at a university in Manta. She has been in the communal bank for 2 years now and she likes the loans because they help her to finance her business. 

Diana, in order to help more with  her educational expenses, since her husband doesn't have enough to pay for them, started a small business in her house with the help of the loans. She sells sodas, water, juice and more. That is how she is able to earn something on her own and keep studying and planning on a better future for her and for her children when she has them.

This loan is to buy water, juice and sodas. Her dreams are to finish her education and have her own house, because they live with relatives.

loans.use: to buy water, juice and sodas.

loans.name: Grâce Group

texts.fr: La cliente Miderwa est une conseillère de l’association d’affaire « Grâce ». Entrepreneur, âgée de 42 ans et mère de 5 enfants qui tous étudient.  La cliente est veuve. Elle  est une vendeuse des souliers au marché public. Il y a 9 ans qu’elle exerce cette activité. Elle commença cette activité avec son fonds propre reçu de son époux, avant sa mort. Grâce à ce commerce, elle a réalisé plusieurs projets en faveur de ses enfants orphelins. Ce nouveau prêt lui servira d’acheter 10 sacs de souliers. En plus, elle souhaite voir ses enfants avoir des diplômes universitaires et accroitre son activité. Au finish, elle salue l’initiative Hekima pour son soutien et autonomisation des femmes non bancables surtout dans le contexte actuel de la guerre à l’Est de la République Démocratique du Congo où l’économie n’est pas stable.
texts.en: This client, Miderwa, is a counselor of the business group "Grace". She is a 42-year-old businesswoman and has five children, all of whom are in school. She is a widow. She has been selling shoes at the public market for nine years. She began this business with her own finances, which were provided by her husband before his death. Thanks to this business, she has accomplished several projects to help her fatherless children. This new loan will serve to buy ten bags of shoes. In addition, she hopes to expand her business and to see her children obtain their university degrees. Finally, she acknowledges the Hekima initiative for supporting and helping women become independent, especially those without access to finances because of the current war in the eastern region of the Democratic Republic of Congo, where the economy is not stable.

loans.use: To buy 10 bags of shoes.

loans.name: Komoga 1 Group

texts.fr:
Les membres du groupe KOMOGA 1 sont toutes  des femmes mariées  ayant une moyenne d’âge de  25 ans, 4 enfants et vivant toutes dans des  familles polygames à  Bandiagara, 5ème région administrative du Mali. 
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de mener à bien leurs activités maraîchères en cette fin d’hivernage. 
Elles sont à leur premier prêt avec l’institution.
La spéculation cultivée est essentiellement l’oignon avec Mme Déné debout  en première  position de la gauche  vers la droite sur la photo. 
Avec son prêt, elle compte acheter  de la semence et des engrais. La production est vendue au niveau du village et de Bandiagara, après la récolte à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes. 
Elle compte réaliser un bénéfice de 24000  Francs CFA en fin de campagne Ce bénéfice lui permettra d’aider son mari dans les dépenses familiales et réinvestir le reste dans les activités.
texts.en:
The members of the "Komoga 1" group are all married women, on average 25 years old with four children, who live in polygamous households in Bandiagara, the fifth administrative region of Mali.
They work with the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso in order to manage their market gardening businesses at the end of the rainy season.
They are on their first loan with the institution.
Ms. Déné, standing all the way on the left in the photo, grows mainly onions.
With her loan, she intends to buy seeds and fertilizer. The produce is sold at the town level and in Bandiagara after the harvest to a clientele comprising men and women.
She intends to realize a profit of 24,000 FCFA at the end of the season. This profit will allow her to help her husband with the family expenses, and also to invest in her farming activity.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and seeds.

loans.name: Virgen Del Carmen Group

texts.es:
El grupo llamado Virgen Del Carmen está en su ciclo número 1 es un grupo nuevo, pero con muchas expectativas de poder crecer e ir mejorando en sus emprendimientos y ayudar a su familia. Ellas están haciendo la encuesta de eliminación de pobreza para poder conocer la situación de cada una.
Una de las integrantes es la Sra. Odilia, quien tiene un comedor, donde día a día alimenta a muchas personas, deleitándolos con las delicias que ella hace. Comenta que con mucho esfuerzo está  saliendo adelante y ayuda a su familia.
Solicita de este crédito para poder invertirlo en la compra de insumos para elaborar los alimentos que ofrece a sus clientes, y comprar fideos, arroz, verduras, carne, condimentos y demás. Agradece por la oportunidad que está recibiendo de seguir creciendo y ayudar a su familia.
texts.en:
The group called Virgen del Carmen is in its first cycle. It is a new group, but they have high expectations of being able to grow and improve their businesses and to help their families. They are taking part in the Poverty Stoplight program to help them determine the situation of each one.

One of the members is Odilia, who has a dining area, where every day she feeds many people, delighting them with the temptations she creates. She says that through a lot of hard work she is getting ahead and helping her family. She is asking for this loan in order to invest it in the purchase of supplies to make the meals she offers her customers, buying noodles, rice, vegetables, meat, condiments, and more. She is grateful for the opportunity that she is receiving to continue growing and helping her family.

loans.use: to buy noodles, rice, vegetables, meat, condiments, and other items in order to prepare her meals for her business

loans.name: Rosita

texts.en:
Rosita is a 54-year-old woman from the town of Albur, Bohol. She is married with nine children. The oldest child is 14 years of age. Her husband is a fisherman, and his income helps support their family. She engages in a business selling fish. She sells fish to customers in the community to help augment the income of their household. Her business started 10 years ago. She is asking for a loan to buy a variety of fresh fish and a fishing net to improve her catch.

In the future, she hopes to expand her fishing business and increase her business profitability for her children’s education.

loans.use: to  buy a variety of fresh fish and a fishing net

loans.name: Emprendedoras Group

texts.es:
El grupo llamado EMPRENDEDORAS está en su ciclo número ocho del programa de comité de mujeres, donde todas trabajan y se ayudan por salir adelante, para poder mejorar en las actividades que cada una hace y también así poder ofrecer un mejor futuro a sus familias.
María es parte de este grupo, quien cosméticos, y por medio de este trabajo procura para poder ayudar a su familia que lo necesita bastante. Ella es una persona muy trabajadora y por sobre todo emprendedora, que pese a los desafíos que se le presentan sabe sobrellevarlos y salir adelante.
La Sra. Solicita de este crédito para la compra de cosméticos variados, y así seguir con su venta, dar a sus clientas una buena variedad atractiva y seguir luchando por mejorar y crecer.
texts.en:
The group called the "EMPRENDEDORAS" is in their 8th cycle with the Woman's Committee Program. The members work and help each other to get ahead and to improve the activity that each one is involved in. They want to offer a better future for their families. 

María is part of this group. She sells cosmetics. Through this work she is able to provide much needed help to her family. She is an enterprising and hard-working person who in spite of the challenges she faces, knows how to overcome them and move forward.

María is requesting this loan to buy various cosmetics. She wants to continue with her sales offering her clients an attractive variety of goods and continue struggling to improve and grow.

loans.use: to buy cosmetics for resale.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to increase her current inventory levels, hence allowing her to sell greater quantities of maize and porridge

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy a computer to support his studies.

loans.name: Elias

texts.en:
Elias is 36 years old. He is married and they have four children. He would like to use his Kiva loan to support labor costs and buy fertilizers during maize production. He needs to buy fertilizer in order to increase production. With profits from his farming he wishes to invest in his business so that in the future he can acquire machines and tractors that will enhance his farming capacity.

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: To buy more fertilizers and support labor costs during maize production.

loans.name: Edna

texts.en:
As a married mother of seven children, Edna works hard to support her family.

She has a general store business in the Philippines, and also earns additional income from 'tricycle' transportation. Edna is borrowing PHP 10,000 through NWTF in order to purchase more groceries to sell.

Edna has been sustaining her business activities through her past four loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase more groceries to sell.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To pay her daughter’s tuition fee

loans.name: Consilida

texts.en:
Consilida, aged 42, has two children and has been in the farming business for the past six years. She would like to use a Kiva loan to support labor costs and buy fertilizers during maize production.  She needs to buy fertilizer in order to increase production. With profits from her farming, she wishes to invest in her business so that in the future she can acquire machines and tractors that will enhance her farming capacity.

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: To buy more fertilizers and supports labor costs during maize productioin.

loans.name: Sokhom

texts.en: Sokhom is 44 years old. She is married and resides with four children in Kampong Speu Province, Cambodia. She has been selling rice for more than three years, earning approximately $10 daily. Her husband helps her run the business. Three of her children are employed in a garment factory. They earn about $11 each day. Due to lack of funds, Sokhom is requesting a loan of $1000 to purchase timber to build up her house walls. This money will help provide better living conditions for the family. In the future, she would like to purchase a small truck to carry her rice to sell in the community and help her youngest child get higher education.

loans.use: to purchase timber to build her house walls

loans.name: Sokhom

texts.en: Sokhon is 29 years old. She is married and resides with a one year-old child in Kampong Speu Province, Cambodia. She has been working in a garment factory for more than three years, earning approximately $3 daily. Her husband is a construction worker who makes an income of $3 each day. In order to improve her family’s finances, Sokhom is requesting a loan of $1000 to purchase a motorbike and a trailer. This purchase will help her run a new business of carrying water to sell and generate more income for the family. In the future, she would like to expand her business and build a new house as soon as possible.

loans.use: to purchase a motorbike and a trailer

loans.name: Jocelyn

texts.en:
Jocelyn is very thankful for the financial assistance extended to her. She used the loan for her computer shop and her business is continuously growing. She has this business for four years now. Aside from her computer shop, she also has a variety store for additional income. Her loan is also helpful for the education of her child. She continues to work to provide for their everyday needs.

She would like to apply for another 50,000 PHP loan to buy additional computer parts and supplies needed in her business. Her profits from her business will definitely help her to cover their daily needs and the educational expenses of her child. She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart.

Jocelyn hopes that her business will continue to flourish and dreams of giving her child a good life. She meets up with her co-fellowship members to share stories of her work every week.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To pay for additional computer parts and supplies needed in her business.

loans.name: Ega

texts.en: Ega is grateful for the previous loan that helped her to buy maize and wheat flour, rice, detergents, and other supplies for her store. Here again, she comes to you requesting another loan of 50,000 Kenyan shillings to buy additional stock like bundles of wheat flour, rice, milk, sugar and soaps for sale. She appreciates the support.

loans.use: to buy bundles of wheat flour, rice, milk, sugar and soaps for sale.

loans.name: Ana Gloria

texts.es: Ana de 64 años de edad vive junto a su grupo familiar el cual está constituido por su compañero de vida y sus cuatro hijos dos de los cuales se encuentran estudiando.  Ella y su  compañero de vida trabajan duramente para llevar el sustento a su hogar. Es una  mujer trabajadora, responsable y emprendedora. Su deseo es dar mejores condiciones a sus hijos. Su principal patrimonio es su humilde casa que con muchos esfuerzos van mejorando junto con su compañero de vida. Con el fin de dar mayor seguridad e higiene a su casa ha tomado la decisión de solicitar este crédito a FUSAI para invertir en la compra de lámina galvanizada, clavos y madera para cambiar el techo  ya que se encuentra deteriorado y además comprar cemento y arena para encementar el piso. Espera poder contar con este apoyo y así  hacer las mejoras necesarias.
texts.en:
Ana is 64 years old She lives with her family which consists of her life-partner and four children, two of whom are studying. She and her partner work hard in order to support their home. She is a hardworking woman, responsible and enterprising, She wants to give her children better conditions.

Her main asset is her humble home that through hard work she and her partner have been improving. With the idea of improving the security and home hygiene she has made the decision of asking for a loan through FUSAI in order to invest in the purchase of galvanized sheets, nails and wood in order to replace the roof which is damaged as well as to buy cement and sand in order to put in a concrete floor.

She is hoping for this support so that she can make the necessary improvements.

loans.use: to buy galvanized sheets, nails, and wood in order to replace the roof and put in a concrete floor.

loans.name: Alphonse

texts.en:
Alphonse is married with two children. He has been in his business for the past six years. He would like to use his Kiva loan to support labor costs and buy fertilizers during maize production. He needs to buy fertilizer in order to increase production. With profits from his farming he wishes to invest in his business so that in the future he can acquire machines and tractors that will enhance his farming capacity.

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: To buy more fertilizers and support labor costs during maize production

loans.name: Guadalupe

texts.es: Guadalupe de 50 años de edad habita junto a su grupo familiar el cual está conformado por su compañero de vida, hijo, nuera y pequeña nieta. Ella se dedica a la venta de verduras y frutas en el mercado de su comunidad.  Ella cuenta con una casa muy humilde hecha de lámina la cual se encuentra deteriorada. Su deseo es levantar una pequeña casa  de ladrillo en su terreno que con mucho esfuerzo ha logrado conservar.  Solicita este crédito a FUSAI para invertir en la compra de cemento, hierro, arena,  grava y lámina para la construcción de su vivienda. Espera poder contar con este préstamo ya que no cuenta con el monto total para hacer dicha inversión pero si tiene la capacidad de pago para cumplir dicho compromiso.
texts.en:
Guadalupe is 50 years old. She lives with her family which consists of her life partner, her son, her daughter-in-law and her young granddaughter. She sells fruits and vegetables in the market of her community. She lives in a very modest house made of metal sheeting which is falling apart. Her wish is to construct a small brick home on her land which she has held on to with great effort. 

Guadalupe has requested a loan from FUSAI to invest in buying cement, re-bar, sand, gravel and metal sheeting to build her house. She hopes to be able to count on this loan as she doesn't have all the money needed for the project. But she does have the capacity to pay off the loan.

loans.use: to buy cement, re-bar, sand, gravel and metal sheeting to build her house.

loans.name: Reverien

texts.en:
Reverien is 38 years old. He is married to a farmer and together, they have five children. He would like to use his Kiva loan to support labor costs and buy fertilizers during maize production. He needs to buy fertilizer in order to increase production. With profits from his farming he wishes to invest in his business so that in the future he can acquire machines and tractors that will enhance his farming capacity.

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers and support labor costs during maize production

loans.name: Donathile

texts.en:
Donathile is 25 years old. She is married and they have one child. With this loan, she will support labor costs and buy fertilizers needed during maize production. She needs to buy fertilizer in order to increase her maize production. With profits from her farming, she wishes to invest in her business so that in the future she can acquire machines and tractors that will enhance her farming capacity.

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: To buy more fertilizers and support labor costs during maize production

loans.name: Ma

texts.en:
From Baray district of Kampong Thom province, Ma, aged 35, is married with three children and is a farmer, primarily growing rice and cassava on several plots of land for later sale. Having been in this type of business for many years, he is able to generate a net profit of KHR 26,000 per day on average. His wife also assists him in managing their farm, besides taking care of the household.

At the moment, he has requested a loan in the amount of KHR 1,000,000 to hire local laborers to weed his cassava plantation. He hopes that the loan will allow him to maintain good production and earn more profit when he sells the produce at the market. He awaits your kindness and relies on your generosity.

loans.use: to hire local laborers to weed his cassava plantation.

loans.name: Kpondo

texts.en: Kpondo lives in Sinkor, is 34 years old, and is married with three children between the ages of 12 and 16 years old. Her husband is a businessman. For the past three years she has been selling palm oil and other items in the local market. She started this business with money given to her by her husband, and learned this way of selling from her mother. She is requesting a loan to purchase more palm oil and many other items for her business. Her plan is to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase more palm oil and many other items for her business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy cement, sand, and galvanized sheets in order to finish making improvements to the floor and hallway of his house.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase increased amounts of Agro chemicals

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase a greater quantity of cassava and maize, thus increasing her current inventory levels

loans.name: Chyngyz

texts.en:
Chyngyz is a student of the American University of Central Asia, department of International and Business Law. Here his story:

“The main thing for a person is the right profession. I want to become a lawyer. To get a high quality education, I enrolled at AUCA, department of International and Business Law. I think that is the most prestigious university in Central Asia which has American system of studies. In the future, when I become a highly qualified lawyer, I want to help people in my country. The moral satisfaction from daily work is a highest salary which isn’t measured by monetary units. Being a true lawyer is to be an expert with the high qualified education.

AUCA is one of the universities that give good opportunities for studies and even financial aid to all its students. I am not able to cover all my tuition fees; therefore I am applying for a Kiva loan, which will be of much help to me. All my thoughts and attention will be fully directed to my studies rather than thinking how to get money and pay for my education.”

loans.use: To pay for his higher education.

loans.name: Sarun's Group

texts.en:
A mother of six children residing in Thmor Koul district of Battambang province, Sarun is 30 years old and a local farmer who does rice farming as the primary source of income. She can generate an average income from her business of about 26,000 KHR per day. This is not the first loan for Sarun with VisionFund (Kiva’s partner). This is the eighth cycle for Sarun and one of her co-borrowers, and the sixth cycle for the remaining member. 

Sarun has managed her past loans wisely to upgrade her lifestyle and make it better than before. For this cycle, she teamed up with two others to form a group of three to get a new loan. Sarun will spend her loan portion to buy fertilizer for her crop. She hopes to boost her crop output in a  timely manner so that she can make more income to keep her kids in school until tertiary level.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer for her crop

loans.name: Annie

texts.en:
Here is Annie from Liberia. She lives in Sinkor,  is 49 years old, and she is a widow. She is a second grade dropout. Since 1998 she has been selling 'fufu' (dough made from pounded cassava) and charcoal in the local market in order to help her children and her household. A challenge she faces is the rainy season.

Anniee started this business with little amount from her family members. She says handling her own money makes her happy about her business. She is requesting a loan to purchase more 'fufu' and charcoal for her business. She wants to expand her business and own a house in the near future.

loans.use: to purchase more 'fufu' and charcoal for her business.

loans.name: Nathan

texts.en:
Nathan is a farmer in Mitozo Kyangyenyi in the Bushenyi District, and he has been doing farming since 1980. 

He is married and the father of 10 children, three of whom are still in school. He works six days and usually takes rest on Sundays. 

He says he started farming with a hope of getting enough money to educate his children so they get quality education. He hopes to use the loan money of three million shilings to buy mulches and fertilizer, which he believes will boost the fertility of the soil and hence he will harvest much.

His clients are the business community in his area since they are the ones who buy the coffee and tea he harvests. His main challenge is the unfavorable weather which can hurt his yields. 

With his honesty and hard work, he hopes to achieve the dream of paying all school dues and giving all his children the best education.

In the picture is Nathan with his wife (who also signed the waiver form).

loans.use: To buy mulches and fertilizer

loans.name: Samei

texts.en: Samei is 53 years old and married. She is blessed with six children, one of whom still counts on her. The main sources of her income are from working for others for a fee and from her husband's occupation as a motor-taxi driver. This is the third loan for Samei with VisionFund (Kiva’s partner). She has wisely managed her past loans to improve her living conditions, making them better than before. Now she wants to help her daughter who wants to pursue a bachelor's degree majoring in Management. Therefore, she applied for an education loan to pay for her daughter's tuition fees. She hopes that her daughter can get a good job after graduation.

loans.use: To pay for her daughter's tuition fees

loans.name: Silvia Cecilia

texts.es: Silvia de 24 años de edad,  es madre soltera y habita en casa propia junto a su pequeño hijo. Ella se dedica a la prestación de servicios domésticos y de esta forma logra llevar el alimento a su hogar.  Su casa es muy pequeña y humilde que con  muchos esfuerzos  ha hecho algunas mejoras.
